Comment: If we're going to have an honest debate, we should all use the actual facts:
Congress in Section 6(i) of the Statehood Act prohibited the state from parting with
the title to its minerals. This section says, in part: The grants of mineral lands to the State of Alaska . . . are made upon the express condition that all sales, grants, deeds, or patents for any of the mineral lands so granted shall be subject to and contain a reservation to the State of all of the minerals in the lands so sold, granted, deeded, or patented . . . . Mineral deposits.   So when we asked for statehood we agreed that the STATE would retain ownership of the mineral tights.  Hence our constitution incorporates this mandate in dealing with mineral rights, holding in Section 8.11 that even when land was granted, the mineral rights were RESERVED by the State.    The State is required by section 8.2 of the constitution the develop is resources "for the maximum benefit of its people."  We have never been "owners".

Comment: Ken,  
Although I think 'will' was obviously a part of it, I saw an even greater difference in the level of execution in this game.  When you have your body in the right place and in the correct football position, a positive outcome is much more likely than when you are out of position running around like a chicken with your head cut off.  And that difference is not 'will', but rather knowledge and execution.   

A great example of this is Utah's first touchdown, on which Troy Dye never got himself into football position, but rather tripped over his own feet awkwardly looking and allowing the touchdown.  He was running fast (too fast) and no one has ever questioned Dye's 'will'.  But if Troy had executed with his body in a football position he would have most likely made the tackle for a loss on that play.

The Ducks executed better.  Only 5 penalties.  Defensive line bodies lower than the Utah offensive linemen and staying in their assigned gaps.  And win or lose it was fun to watch.

Comment: The City Council reveals how clueless they are about rail funding.  They knew that the GET surcharge won't pay for HART salaries, so the City will have to come up with the money from its own sources, such as the property tax.  But it seems that they are perplexed about how to do it.  City Budget Director Nelson Koyanagi recommends using bonds.  However, Councilmember Ann Kobayashi says that it's unprecedented to use bonds to pay for operating costs.  She's right because the use of bonds would restrict the capacity of the City to pay for core services in the future.  Funding operating costs with bonds is a desperate idea.  It shows that the City does not have a rational long-term financing plan for rail.

Comment: The best way to promote innovation is to remove the barriers to entry to innovators, and to lower their transaction costs so that innovative products can get to market more easily.
.
Education is an excellent start.
.
But so, too, is making it so that they don't waste 90 minutes/day commuting.
So, too, is not having the creative sector (and everybody else) subsidise e.g., minerals extraction, through a lop-sided tax system.
.
Promoting innovation is not about picking winners and losers in innovative technologies - the market generally does that pretty well for us. 
.
It is about making Canada an attractive place for innovators to live, both in terms of their business activities and in terms of general ease of living - which means good transportation and communications, good child care, reliable public utilities, and healthy living environments.
.
If you create an environment where it is easy for creative innovators to live and work, they will take care of the innovation themselves.

Comment: I was sent to emerg in Mississauga by my Ophthalmologist to get a blood test for a possible  condition prior to my eye surgery. I was suffering a headache over the right eye as well. I get the whole triage concept. Heaven knows, I've seen enough medical shows. But, when your problem is not considered important by those who make such decisions, you will NEVER get assistance.

For there will always be someone whose medical issue is worse than yours.

Comment: As a physician practising for 38 years, I still have to pay for my staff of 3 people, office rent, my office and clinic business and medical supplies, my accountant, my lawyer and all the other expenses that go into running a small business.  My wife works full time in my office.  I have no pension plan from OHIP.  My Ontario Medical Association Drug Benefit Plan has a $ 1000 deductible before reimbursement of any medical expenses and we have no dental plan. I have no paid vacation - as a specialist if I don't work, I don't get paid anything.

Very few physicians make 1 million dollars a year - the rest of us are slugging it out for much less working 60-80 hours per week.  In the past, instead of fee increases, we were allowed to incorporate to build up some retirement income.  As an incorporated physician, I pay income tax on what is withdrawn as income to support myself and will pay full taxes owing at the end when the corporation is wrapped up.

What does Mr. Trudeau want to prove?

Comment: Being a constitutional republic does not mean we should not and cannot guarantee the election of the presidential candidate with the most popular votes. The candidate with the most votes wins in every other election in the country.

Guaranteeing the election of the presidential candidate with the most popular votes and the majority of Electoral College votes (as the National Popular Vote bill would) would not make us a pure democracy. 

Pure democracy is a form of government in which people vote on all policy initiatives directly. 

Popular election of the chief executive does not determine whether a government is a republic or pure democracy.

The presidential election system, using the 48 state winner-take-all method or district winner method of awarding electoral votes used by 2 states, that we have today was not designed, anticipated, or favored by the Founding Fathers.

Comment: That isn't true. The timber industry shut down for a number of reasons, the primary one being the collapse of the housing market. Secondarily, mill jobs disappeared because of mechanization and CAD/CAM. The overcutting of the 70's and 80's decimated the old forests and killed the mills set up to handle big logs. Environmental  protest is in there too, but in general it only stopped logging of specific cutting units. The spotted owl set-asides are the only reason we have any old growth remaining; you won't find it on private land. Private sales of unmilled logs to China bypass our own mills. Even our chips are sold to China. Logging jobs are reduced by three-fourths owing to machines like faller-bunchers, shovel-loaders, limber-trimmers and tracked yarders. The children of loggers are mostly out of work, living in single-wides with dead cars in the front yard, and drugs are a big problem.

Comment: I often find non-indigenous people quick to take offence, especially when arguing that indigenous people shouldn't.  I'm not indigenous either -- but this is not just about "free speech" and I'm simply raising another aspect of the issue in terms that are "mainstream", ie, economic and legal terms.  

As for copyright, trademark, etcetera, isn't part of the problem that those laws don't address concepts of collective authorship and ownership in indigenous communities?  If one person writes a story, they can get a copyright.  If a story is collectively developed and orally passed on in a community, it can't be copyrighted and they are left without any legal protection for something they created.  There are also cases where indigenous groups have applied for trade marks for indigenous forms and have been refused -- that leaves them with no business case to invest in developing and marketing a product, so they don't, and that's a shame.

Comment: AFAIK I haven't been limited to one comment a day although I have had a few warnings and today I got a "final warning" which made me think if I don't judge someone else's comment correctly I would lose my account completely.

But seriously how hard would it be to set up another one?  It would be a minor inconvenience,

It does seem to have cut down on some of the more trollish and hateful comments but I don't think it's that great.

No system is perfect but I prefer something more like what slashdot does.  It's too complicated to explain here, but posts get rated between a -1 and +5 and if you only browse comments rated +4 or above (for example) you're likely not to see anything uncivil.

And the comments are moderated by other posters there as well.  Which reminds me - I've got 15 mod points to burn.   I hardly ever use them all.

Often the best comments are already modded up and I don't mod posts down just because I disagree with them.

Comment: I'm a licensed massage therapist. I carry my own professional liability insurance, just like a doctor, only mine's a lot cheaper because LMT's hardly ever get sued!! If you stay within your "scope of practice" your chances of damaging someone are very, very small. Also, any business (like a spa for example) that hires LMTs will also cover them under their liability insurance.  If the accused in this lawsuit is able to back up his treatment with good notes, as we are all supposed to keep on every client, then this will die quickly in court. If he did not take good notes, and ends up his word against hers, then he or his insurer might have to pay up.  Personally I would never go to a therapist whose majority of clients are using a Groupon! A highly skilled therapist charges $60 - $80 per hour and is worth every penny.

Comment: Bill Morneau continues to describe these as "loopholes" (defn.: "an ambiguity or omission in the text through which the intent of a statute, contract, or obligation may be evaded").  In fact, he's referring to deliberate government policy that small business owners were encouraged to pursue.  Moreover, and most importantly, these rules provide no after-tax advantages to individuals.  Market forces would quickly erode any such riskless advantage.  As an example, imagine plumbers suddenly paid no tax - would plumbers be wealthier in the long run.  No.  More plumbers would enter the market, driving down prices (to the good of consumers) and profits, until plumbers earned exactly as much  as they originally did relative to other professions.  The only difference is that we'd have more plumbers.  Suddenly charging those plumbers an "equivalent" tax rate would amount to a dramatic reduction in their fair wage.  That's the reason these tax changes are fundamentally unjust.

Comment: Should the content of judicial training be disclosed?

There are two separate questions here: a narrow, precise one, and a broad, general one.  Only the narrow one arises in the Edmonton sexual assault trial.

1. The narrow, precise one:  should it be admissible in this trial? If defence counsel is actually making an allegation that the judge hearing the trial - in fact, any judge hearing the trial - is so biased by his training sessions that no fair trial can be held, then perhaps it's admissible.  I doubt it, though.  I'd say it's the well-known "fishing expedition," and should be dismissed.

2. Of course, that still leaves the bigger question to be answered elsewhere: does the public have the right to know? There's little doubt it's the question most comments here are interested in. But it's not a question for this trial.

Comment: The Corporate tax all comes from increased prices on goods and services. Management will not take a cut, and stockholders will get their profits or sell their stocks and bankrupt the company. No consideration for the income of those charged the higher prices. A completely regressive tax that most profoundly impacts the poor. 

The correct and most humane thing to do is eliminate the regressive corporate tax and replace it with a progressive Fair Tax type income tax with prebates for poverty level spending. Net prices would decline, particularly for the poor because of the prebates, but for everyone else as well because corporations would no longer need to spend hundreds of billions filing tax returns. 

Everyone wins. The govt gets the same amount of revenue or more (probably more, unless you make the new tax really small, 0-2%) and net prices go down for everyone. And a whole section of the IRS can be eliminated, reducing spending and the deficit.

Comment: It's quite astounding to see the amount of comments on any drug-related article that claim getting rid of dealers is the solution. If you do even the *tiniest* amount of research on ways to combat addictions (of any kind) it is GLARINGLY obvious that cutting supplies is a temporary fix, a band-aid. It's a necessary strategy  that could save lives, which makes it worth pursuing to an extent. Countless studies (citations aplenty if requested) show that the majority of resources need to devoted to addressing the underlying problems. What those are and how to deal with them remain moving targets, but there are definitely initiatives that have been proven successful in other regions (and countries) that are more cost-effective than addressing the supply-side. Again, I'm not saying that there shouldn't be any consequences for those supplying these substances, but if that's the primary strategy being utilized, we're fighting a losing battle.

Comment: Simple experiment you can try on your own.

http://nerdist.com/8-reasons-we-know-the-earth-isnt-flat/

"...THE SAME OBJECTS MAKE DIFFERENT SHADOWS
Here‚Äôs one you can try at home. If the Earth were flat, you could drive two sticks into the ground at any place on Earth, and the shadows those sticks would make would be the same length. (Because the Sun is so far away from Earth, its incoming rays can be considered parallel).

Place a stick in the ground on a sunny day, then measure the length of the shadow. At the same time, call a friend who is at least a few miles away from you and tell them to do the same. The lengths you measure will be different! The curvature of a spherical Earth means that sun rays will hit each stick differently if they are far enough apart...."

Comment: I thought weed had a shelf life? 
Cannabis can have an indefinite shelf life, but only if all of the proper conditions have been met. For cannabis to truly stand the sands of time, one must not only handle each process of the growth and harvest cycle carefully, but also store the cannabis properly. If all of these conditions are met, one could be enjoying their favorite strain 10 years from now with little quality degradation.

Unfortunately, not all cannabis is cultivated with this level of precision and since consumers can‚Äôt control the quality of their cannabis before it reaches their hands, having the ability to identify mishandled cannabis that is typically labeled ‚Äúold‚Äù or ‚Äúbad‚Äù is an imperative last line of defense. After all, nobody wants to puff a bowl of bone dry and/or moldy ganja.

Comment: The question should really be: "does the amount of money my advisor is making off my portfolio justify his value?" Even if you only pay 1% and have half a million, then you are paying an advisor $400 per month! Since most active managers don't beat the index over long time periods, most people should be investing in index funds. They would have better long term returns and pay very low fees. So why don't more advisors steer clients toward this approach? Because they can't make money off of index funds. If advisors are supposed to act in their clients best interest then many are either ignorant or in conflict of interest. Alternatively, one could pay a few hundred a year and subscribe to a well respected investor newsletter and simply buy and hold a basked to blue chip dividend paying stocks and pay almost no fees, and probably have better long term returns. It is time for  the public to recognize that many financial advisors earn far too much money for the value they provide.

Comment: The salmon eating Puget Sound orcas are doomed because they are too many for the available food supply.

Yep.  Only it don't work when the water suddenly is over 70degrees F,  and the fish mostly died.  Only 13% of the potential smolts were barged.  The rest cooked.   Oh,  and so that is now bandied about as a good reason to remove the only dams on the entirety of the Snake River with fish ladders.  And in a warming world,  with those dams you lose the locks and the ability to barge the smolts in cold water to where the water is survivable.   The orcas are doomed,  collateral damage in a turf fight inside our Government.

Comment: I don't believe that is correct.  ASL is use in the US and Canada, and possibly one other country, as the major sign language.  it is also taught by U.S. missionaries who go into other countries to minister to the Deaf community, if there isn't a recognized version of sign language already there.

American Sign Lanugage was developed from French sign language when a Deaf teacher of the Deaf (Clerc) was brought from France to teach Deaf children in America.  Brought here by a pastor whose neighbor had a Deaf daughter.  

Deaf children were taught by Deaf teachers until the time of the civil war when it was ruled that teachers of the Deaf had to speak so that effectively ruled out most Deaf teachers.  There is a British sign language, there is a Japanese Sign Language, and many other countries have their own version.  I've heard, though, that Deaf Americans visiting other countries have less difficulty communicating in the native SL, than hearing visitors in spoken language.

She urged that the proponents of Measure 97 and business leaders work out some kind of proposal.  It looks like we continue to have a governor who is a mere office holder and not a leader.

Oregon gets about 87% of its revenue from the state's income tax (per the ODR income tax analysis from 2013) so budget solutions should start there since comprehensive tax reform appears unlikely.
I would recommend the following  revenue enhancements relative to the income tax: (1) eliminate the $95 per person tax credit; (2) eliminate the deduction for federal income taxes paid; (3) end any Earned Income Tax Credits under state law.

The people must vote to repeal the "kicker" and allow the state to retain all revenue received.

This would be a compromise package sure to be disliked and picked apart by both liberals and conservatives.

Comment: Nathan, are you certain that there was an investment loss of 1.2% for 2016?

I ask, because the S&P 500 ended 2016 with a positive return of 12% (11.96%).  In the previous 4 years:  2015, 1.4%; 2014, 14%; 2013,  32%; and 2012, 16%.

Most pension funds allocate between equities and fixed income investments, so the actual returns would be less than the above.  Because interest rates are near zero, and assuming a 50/50 allocation, I'd have expected a positive return of about 6%.

ERS probably has about half dozen independent investment managers.  And I'm sure they are all very good.  Their performances are always compared with each other as well as with the major indices.

So the loss is a mystery to me.

Comment: Part 3...
Canada needs (and can afford) complete national health care

Hospital costs cont'd.
The factors that contribute to the rise of hospital costs include: 1) increase in the compensation of hospital health care providers, accounting for 60% of the total hospital budget; 2) increase in the number of hospital workers (between 1999 and 2008, their number grew by 21%, mainly to meet the need for new services; and 3) introduciton of new and expensive diagnostic and surgical tools (e.g., robotic systems hyperbaric surgery); computers, electronic health records and telehealth).

The options for containing hospital costs include replacing the current system of hospital budgeting with regional population-based budgeting, as in Alberta & saskatchewan, or paying for services provided on the basis of unit cost.

Comment: You're welcome, Kenneth, but I think you missed my point.  I was responding to your statement that " it's false to say that "Native Hawaiians" have the worst statistics" by pointing out that self-identification does seem to work in the cases cited.  That is, self-identified Native Hawaiians *are* more at risk for various diseases, jail time, etc.  These are long established facts, at least since the Native Hawaiians Study Commission report of 1983.

I agree with you that it would be bad if people were self-identifying as Native Hawaiian to "get sympathy or money", but I don't believe that is the case for two reasons.  First, my experience suggests people self-identify today for reasons of pride in their Hawaiian ancestors.  Second, disease risk etc. are established statistically from large samples--it is impossible for the individual to know beforehand the outcome of a statistical test on a large sample.

Comment: My son was born in 1994 and I face regret every single day for not banking his cord blood.  Had I only known that his condition (to which he has spent well over 12 years of daily therapy and still plagues him through adulthood) could have been reversed via his cord blood, well...  it would have changed both of our lives.  The potential for stem cells in cord blood is limitless.  And the likelihood of a match with other members of the family is very good so your baby's cord blood could be used to save his grandparents!  I have known people with sick kids to have another child in hopes of harvesting matching cord blood for a sick child.  For $1,000 and minimal annual fees?  It's a no brainer, imo. EVERY SINGLE DAY, I REGRET NOT HAVING BANKED MY CHILD'S CORD BLOOD.  I think this is a great gift a grandparent can make as new moms have other things on their mind.

Comment: I've explored my feelings on the rail in the past with my Yesterday's Tomorrow cartoons, where I compared the similarities between the rail and the H3 relative to public opinion on both projects at their respective times. I wasn't for rail, but surely I will benefit from it if and when it is completed, along with the next generation of youth who will ride it absolved from the burdens that the current generation has to deal with.

That being said, we face a heavy burden, one that to many does not justify the projected effect the rail would have on alleviating traffic (it simply would not do enough for its cost.)

I wasn't for rail when it was proposed, but now that part of it has been built, I wouldn't consider myself anti-rail. I consider myself anti-how this project has been handled. We might as well make the most of the situation at hand. I'll ride it if it gets built, but if it doesn't, it'd be nice to have a park.

Comment: And in this way the discussion goes 'round in circles. 

Viewing Robert E. Lee as any one thing is inadequate. He wasn't a "kindly old man" until he became one much later in life. The first 50 years of his life he spent as a decorated and highly-regarded military man. And by highly-regarded, I mean throughout the USA, including the north. His job was directing men in battle, not performing acts of kindness. And prior to the Civil War he performed great service to the United States of America in the role he took on.

On the spectrum of his day's views on slavery, Lee was a moderate. Moreover, his views on slavery changed over time. He came to accept and advocate for the new order of things in America. Depicting him as symbol of the evil southern slave-owner does a disservice to history.

Deputy AG Nominee Won't Commit To Special Prosecutor For Russia Probe

Donald Trump's nominee for deputy attorney general on Tuesday declined to commit to appointing a special prosecutor to lead any probe into Russian election interference, including into alleged links between the Trump campaign and Russia.

Since Attorney General Jeff Sessions recused himself from any probe involving the Trump campaign, Rod Rosenstein, the U.S. Attorney in Maryland, would be tasked with leading such an investigation if confirmed. 

Democrats are pushing for Rosenstein to step aside from any probe into ties between Trump and his associates and Russia as well.

Comment: The argument posed here seems wrongheaded. It's true that neither the US nor Canada stand to gain from Buy American/Buy Canadian type policies. That being said, if the US does extend Buy American policies, outside of efforts in the WTO and the courts via NAFTA, reciprocity is the only unitary measure through which we can even hope to return to the "free trade" status quo. Reciprocity via Buy Canadian is not about "winning", it's about responding accordingly to motivate the US to return to more desirable trade relations. What does the author suggest we do instead?  Just bend over and accept it? That is not the answer. If we want to change US trade behavior we must not only respond in kind, we must cooperate with like-minded nations seeking to constrain US bilateral economic behavior,  working in concert to change their behavior. In conducting trade only with nations that promote free trade, we fight the temptation towards insularity and tariff raising which led to WWII. We must act now!

Comment: That's a good broad point.   But the PF was created for the collective benefit of all future generations of Alaska.    The PFD was conceived as a means to distribute this collective benefit individually through payments.    An accrued interest is a right you acquire over time.   There is no "right" to a dividend that was created simply because it has been paid over a long period of time.     It's a gift, not an entitlement.   If the citizens of Alaska wanted to create a "right" to it, then you are correct, we could do so through an initiative.   But presently, it's a annual "gift" as allowed by law.

Comment: The tax increases to the wealthy are relatively small, to be honest. In fact, Bernie's proposed brackets are almost identical the the tax levels that Reagan endorsed in the early 1980s, while running for President. Any income that comes in under the new bracket is taxed at the old levels; it's only the part of your income that exceeds the new bracket thresholds that will be taxed at new levels. So, for example, the first new bracket is $250,000/year. Everything from $249,999 and down will still be taxed at 33%; everything over will be taxed at the new 37% level. The entire set of changes are as follows:

$250,000+/year will be 37%.
$500,000+/year will be 43%.
$2,000,000+/year will be 48%.
$10,000,000+/year will be 52%

I would also point out that his proposed taxation levels, to accomplish all of this, are almost exactly the same as what Reagan repeatedly fought for.

Hurricanes are strengthened by warmer waters, but it isn't correct to say that there has been no evidence of the latter due to increased CO2 emissions. As with the warming of the troposphere (the lower layer of our atmosphere, the one we live in), ocean temperatures have been rising as well. When you seen global temperature mentioned it includes the oceans.

There are a series of graphs on this page that document the warming of the oceans in recent decades:

https://www.nodc.noaa.gov/OC5/3M_HEAT_CONTENT/

The strengths of two massive hurricanes we've just witnessed were affected by warmer surface temperatures. Those temperatures were the result of weather, currents, winds, and other factors, including the effect of gradual warming of the oceans as a result of increasing CO2 emissions.

Comment: It is not allowed to be both enrolled in the Affordable Care Act and in the VA health system.

I so wish this country had national health care, like advanced countries like Canada have.
Hugh Massengill, Eugene

Comment: The bond rating agencies would be the judge of whether the provincial finances are okay or not.  So far they have given good marks to the BC government.  BC has a good credit rating.  If John Horgan and the BC NDP were to run large deficits then the BC government could face a credit downgrade and end up having to pay more interest on their bonds.  If that happened then everyone in BC would have to pay more taxes just to pay the interest on the BC government bonds.

Increased bond issuance from having deficits every year along with having to pay higher interest rates due to a credit downgrade would mean more and more tax revenue would go just to paying interest on the provincial debt instead of going to pay for government programs and services.

So I would rather have Christy Clark win the election and continue to run balanced budgets instead of taking a chance on John Horgan and the NDP.  I don't believe the NDP platform can be put into effect without producing large deficits.

Comment: Way back when the US formed it was always imagined the new union would include the Canadian colonies, even (especially) Quebec. The absence of Canada from the US union was an entirely manageable affair for the two hundred year existence of the United States, even though our absence essentially put the US into imbalance, possibly  one reason the north/south US split became so intransigent so quickly. For two hundred years, we have been an ally and cultural cousin of our neighbours to the south. But increasingly, our absence means bad outcomes for the US and the world.  Canada and the US should become one political entity, possibly with Quebec in a Schengen-like arrangement, and restoring North America as one political space as it had been for centuries. Why vote at the margins, when our votes could tip the US balance of power, and in doing so, shape the world. That's how the world gets more Canada, through a more Canadian America. Union, hope and a more peaceful world.

Comment: The economics certainly don't add up.

Instead of building Site C, Hydro should use the power that BC is entitled to under the Columbia River treaty - over 1,100 MW capacity and 4,000 GWh/yr energy.  But the BC Liberals won't allow it, so instead this power is sold on the market for $30 a MWh, one-third the cost of Site C's energy.

And BC now has smart meters which would allow time-of-use billing to reduce peak loads, further negating the need for Site C.  But the Liberals won't let Hydro take advantage of that either.  

Hydro's debt is spiraling out of control - despite a 46% rate increase from 2014 to 2024, Hydro's debt will grow from $16 billion to $24 billion over the same period.  Clearly not sustainable.

Comment: Why is it assumed that there is a single good way to teach math?  From my own experience there are some students who "get" math, who can easily juggle numbers and equations in their heads and who can pick up new concepts easily.   For others it may be a struggle that requires step by step instruction.   For both groups, I agree that committing certain basic skills to memory is key, and repeated practice is necessary - if only so one learns to avoid sloppy mistakes that we can all make.    As to textbooks, I've worked through a couple of them, and they've been so dumbed down, with every single step written out to the point where the kids no longer need to think that they make the teaching harder rather than easier.   Solutions will come from tackling all these problems, from better trained teachers who can recognize the students who "get it" to those who need more coaching and step by step guidance, to better textbooks, and a willingness to ensure the fundamentals are ingrained early on

Comment: I agree with some of what you say, but the numbers are off.  There are 20% of the old growth forests left.  5 million acres in Oregon, with virtually no loss since 1992.   You are correct about the terrain .  That's largely because people did not want to build cities, farms or even houses on that terrain.  The change of the land use (Oregon's old growth forests used to cover 14.2M acres around the turn of the century and now cover 5M) is due to a number of things including people settling the land, fire, logging, pathogens, etc.
The history of Oregon's land is rich and fascinating, but the fact remains that the timber industry cannot currently mill old growth logs.  Their mills are tooled for second growth.  They could not run a 60-inch-diameter log through their mills if they wanted to.  Andy Kerr's depiction of timber companies wanting to chop down old growth forests with bulldozers at the ready is a false one. He's either out of touch, or trying to incite the uneducated.

Comment: Outsider, I agree and not all dams are bad.  Micro hydro generators in certain areas make a lot of sense. Recently as an experiment, I replaced my plastic 3/4 inch main water lines with copper.  It increased my water velocity, my water at the tap/shower also got hotter much faster, and I noticed I have turned down my hot water control valves because the water is hotter.  So much that I thought my hot water tank setting was accidentally turned-up.  An added small benefit of copper, it is a "natural" static water purifier.

Comment: The problem with long-term solutions is that they ARE long term.  If you are a small business owner barely breaking even or a member of the general public, then ideas that may prove effective in a generation or two really don't matter.  No citizen should have to wait 20 or more years to avail themselves of clean and safe sidewalks, public parks, beaches, and public toilet facilities. 

Not at all saying your ideas lack merit, but if it comes down to a choice between directing funds and other resources for enforcement that can benefit most of Hawaii's adults and children right now, instead if efforts that may bear fruit only after they've grown old or moved away, then I'd have to choose the former. 

Much as we'd all like to have everyone highly educated with a safe place to live and making a good living, sometimes society in general just doesn't have money or the time and patience to do it all and for everyone.

Comment: What, exactly, everyone expects the PM to do? The current job market didn't just come into being when we elected Trudeau - it's been forming steadily since the 1980s. I graduated high school in 1980, and already the idea that one would get a job and work there for life and then retire was a thing of the past. Sure, it still existed, but it was rare and getting rarer. I, myself, worked as a temp for much of the 80s and put myself through university on temp jobs. In over three decades of work (four if you count all the part time jobs I held through high school), I've only had one full-time job for any length of time working in publishing - about 12 years - after which I started my own company so now I work more than full time for myself. And my experience is shared by most of the people I know my age and even older. Plus, so many of the 9 to 5 'steady' jobs of the past were related to resource extraction or factory work - is that what these students want? More 9 to 5 drudgery jobs?

Comment: Nick - I would be delighted if climate activists were showing up to argue for both density and housing affordability. Instead, they are mostly not showing up to the comprehensive plan hearings at all. Density, as Angus Duncan of the state climate change commission points out, is key to climate policy. If 7,00 people live within walking distance of each other, a grocery store will spring up to serve them that they can walk to, rather than drive. Density is critical to the viability of transit; the reason the New York subway system is economically viable is that there are a lot of people per stop. I think it's important for people who care about the climate to explain that to their fellow citizens. As to gentrification, cause gentrification; what causes gentrification is rich people moving here. If we built zero new housing, the rich people moving in would still drive up the price of the existing housing.

Comment: TOU pricing only makes economic sense when total power usage nears or exceeds the available power supply. At present, Ontario has an an almost perpetual oversupply of power and often has to give the stuff away to neighbouring jurisdictions. The system is so absurd that some sources of power, like solar, tend to be more available at times the government wants people consuming less power, like weekday afternoons. And who can predict when the wind will blow? Further, nuclear power, which Ontario uses for its base load, isn't particularly flexible and is neither any cheaper nor more expensive to produce depending on the time of day. Gas and hydroelectric are used for peaking, but as the system is overproducing electricity in general in comparison to demand, TOU pricing may actually be undermining the economic viability of these power sources.

Comment: The bigger story is why voters continue to re-elect the BC Liberals.

Part of that reason can be laid at the feet of the msm, who for the most part  have given the BC Liberals a free ride when it comes to investigative reporting.

When the Campbell Liberals defeated the NDP years ago, they were handed a budget surplus of over 1.5 billion.  But the BC Liberals had campaigned on the (false) premise that the NDP were bad stewards of the economy, and had fudged their optimistic budget.

So the BC Liberals hid the surplus, and in the transition ceremony Gordon Campbell stated  ""Some of the problems that we face are as we thought and some are worse than we thought," he said, "The finances of the province are worse than we anticipated." 

Msm headlines "screamed that the defeated NDP had left behind a fiscal mess for the new government. "B.C. Finances Worse Than Thought, Campbell Says," blared The Vancouver Sun."

The damage was done, and the NDP's image as fiscally responsible shattered.

Comment: True, but Kenai grew up around oil and MatSu is not used to having oil around drinking water wells and quiet homes with some dogs around. I am not saying absolutely no exploration. We have had relatively long term thinking operators on the  spectrum of more responsible. Most Alaska petroleum development is not near residential areas. Kenai grew up around the fields, and Nikiski ended up very different from Homer. Also, the platforms have limited access docks, and Swanson is kind of tucked back & away from homes. There are a few deep gas reservoirs under residential areas at the mouth of the Kenai and Ninilckik... but Ninilckik has more landowners with subsurface royalties. Comment: They both suck I agree.  But just because you hate one party doesn't mean you have to follow the other.

Think for yourself, and research facts on health care in other countries.

Obamacare sucks because it didn't get rid of the insurance companies.  Instead it said they had to pay out 80% on costs, so hospitals jacked up prices and insurance companies gladly paid it because their 20% went up.

Insurance companies need to be removed.  Medicare is much more efficient.  When you remove the executive salaries, paper pushers, claims rejectors etc. it saves a lot of money.

Costs at hospitals need to be regulated.  In Japan an MRI cost $91.  In the US it's +$5,000.

The free market doesn't work because we don't have that many choices and we don't tend to shop around during an emergency.

Comment: The author missed mentioning a very important woman deacon for St. Paul. A notable woman in the church of Cenchreae, she was trusted by Paul to deliver his letter to the Romans.[1] In writing to the church that almost surely met in her home,[2] Paul refers to her both as a deacon (Gk. diakonon masc.) and as a helper or patron of many (Gk. prostatis).
